Issues.Title: this.route.navigate function is not working as expected
Issues.Body:
I'm using Angular 8 and faced some problems with routing when I'm using lazy-loaded child modules.

>app-routing.module.ts

```typescript
...
const routes: Routes = [
   {
      path: :id,
      component: ParentComponent,
      children: [
         { path: 'child', loadChildren: './child.module#ChildModule' }
      ]
   }
]
...
```

>child-routing.module.ts

```typescript
...
const routes: Routes = [
   { path: 'child1', component: Child1Component },
   { path: 'child2', component: Child2Component }
]
...
```

Now, we have routing in these ways.
foo.com/123/child/child1 -> Child1Component
foo.com/123/child/child2 -> Child2Component

Here, I tried to navigate to foo.com/123/child/child2 inside Child1Component.
I was thinking child module is apart from app module and it's lazy loaded so this code will be working correctly.

>child2.component.ts
```typescript
...
constructor(private router: Router) {}

...
this.router.navigate(['child/child2']);
...
```

But once I launched the application, it is navigated to foo.com/child/child2.
I was expecting foo.com/123/child/child2.

If I make these changes, it's working as expected.
>child2.component.ts
```typescript
...
private parentId;
constructor(private router: Router, private route: ActivatedRoute) {
   this.route.parent.parent.params.subscribe((params) => {this.parentId = params.id});
}

...
this.router.navigate([this.parentId, 'child', 'child2']);
...
```

It's getting parentId from the URL inside the component and navigate using it.
But I don't like this approach because it's not scalable.
If I change the Route Param name or add some more routing params, I have to update the child components for routing as well.

Is there any better approach for handling routing in child components defined on child module lazy-loaded?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "this.route.navigate function is not working as expected" (#33497)

Issues.Title: fix(compiler-cli): attach the correct `viaModule` to namespace imports
Issues.Body:
Previously declarations that were imported via a namespace import
were given the same `bestGuessOwningModule` as the context
where they were imported to. This causes problems with resolving
`ModuleWithProviders` that have a type that has been imported in
this way, causing errors like:

```
ERROR in Symbol UIRouterModule declared in
.../@uirouter/angular/uiRouterNgModule.d.ts
is not exported from
.../@uirouter/angular/uirouter-angular.d.ts
(import into .../src/app/child.module.ts)
```

This commit modifies the `TypescriptReflectionHost.getDirectImportOfIdentifier()`
method so that it also understands how to attach the correct `viaModule` to
the identifier of the namespace import.

Resolves #32166
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(compiler-cli): attach the correct `viaModule` to namespace imports" (#33495)

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/*


### Description
After some years of Angular programming I've been noticing the same issues repeating itself over and over again. And that issue is a lack of information given by Angular when stuff goes wrong.

For instance, I've been refactoring some code, afterwards I wanted to run a build to see if everything was still in order.

Sadly, I was faced with the following errors:

```
ERROR in Cannot determine the module for class DbValueComponent in /lib/db-value/db-value.component.ts! Add DbValueComponent to the NgModule to fix it.

Cannot determine the module for class DbInputComponent in /lib/db-input/db-input.component.ts! Add DbInputComponent to the NgModule to fix it.
```

So then you think, alright lets take a look in my ngModule see if everything's in order. But everything's there. So now the error message became useless, it doesn't point you in the right way at all.

Now this is just a simple example, but this happens too often in my opinion. Greatly reduces efficiency for no apparent gain.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Fix error descriptions so it's actually useful.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
React

Issues.Title: [Feature|Bug][@angular/elements] NgModuleRef remains after CustomElement is removed from DOM
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature & bug  request

### Relevant Package
@angular/elements

### Description
Hi there. We are successfully ([& performant! :yum:](https://twitter.com/simsek_dev/status/1168163228574277639)) implementing the micro frontends approach with the help of **@angular/elements**.
On my weekly performance check of the many applications on the customer side, I realized that the bootstrapped module of an @angular/element remains alive, even after the CustomElement has been removed from the DOM. 
*To think further, this means that every service instance and the hole injection tree is still alive.*

### Describe the solution you'd like
We do have triggers / timestamps to know when to destroy such *NgModuleRefs*, by attaching this to the `disconnectedCallback()`, which is a [specified reaction for CustomElements](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/custom-elements.html#custom-element-reactions).


### Describe alternatives you've considered
We / I can work this around by saving a reference to the bootstraped NgModuleRef and decide manually when to destroy the NgModuleRef, but
**In my opinion this is not an expected behaviour or should be documented at least somewhere.**

Yes, the current approach might share the current NgModuleRef of a given bootstrapped angular application, but the way I understand the concept of CustomElements, everything should be cleaned up after the element is removed from the DOM.
To put it rather dumbly: "Why are the @angular/elements not just create their own NgModuleRef?"
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Feature|Bug][@angular/elements] NgModuleRef remains after CustomElement is removed from DOM" (#33489)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): ComponentFactory.create should clear host element content
Issues.Body:
Prior to this change, ComponentFactory.create function invocation in Ivy retained the content of the host element (in case host element reference or CSS selector is provided as an argument). This behavior is different in View Engine, where the content of the host element was cleared, except for the case when ShadowDom encapsulation is used (to make sure native slot projection works). This commit aligns Ivy and View Engine and makes sure the host element is cleared before component content insertion.

This PR resolves FW-1649.

Issues.Title: Ivy can't compile a project that has a library with internal imports sharing same parent directory
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/compiler-cli ### Is this a regression? No it has not worked as far as I know. Related work in #29361 did not resolve the issue I'm facing, though the error reports the same thing. ### Description Ivy is not able to determine the file paths for imports inside of a library in the same CLI project when it is configured in a certain way. It seems to only occur when the library and the application are both inside of the same subdirectory in a project (`src/app` and `src/library`), but seems to work when they are not in the same subdirectory (`src/app` and `projects/library`). This is the only difference that I can determine from various configuration and setups. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/gnomeontherun/angular-9-ivy-library-error Working configuration in separate directories: https://github.com/gnomeontherun/angular-9-ivy-library-error/commit/1443b1139d0a2d814d0acd1c2dbd8d1c1cc05547 Failing configuration in same directory: https://github.com/gnomeontherun/angular-9-ivy-library-error/commit/1f9c7817c2adc75229b4509d061f6d2d4f1c0fbf 1. Clone & `npm install` 2. `ng build` or `ng build --prod` This is also reproducible from Clarity https://github.com/gnomeontherun/clarity/tree/angular9 With Clarity, you can still build the library with Ivy (enable Ivy in tsconfig.prod.json config file inside of clr-angular and run `ng build --prod clr-angular), it is isolated to the sample application that imports the library. ## üî• Exception or Error 

ERROR in Unable to write a reference to ClrAngularComponent in /repo/projects/clr-angular/src/lib/clr-angular.component.ts from /repo/projects/clr-angular/src/lib/clr-angular.module.ts
## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 9.0.0-next.18
Node: 10.16.0
OS: darwin x64
Angular: 9.0.0-next.14
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Package                            Version
------------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect          0.900.0-next.18
@angular-devkit/build-angular      0.900.0-next.18
@angular-devkit/build-ng-packagr   0.900.0-next.18

typescript                         3.6.4

**Anything else relevant?** I tested a lot of things, such as the use of TypeScript paths or not, and everything was working until they were colocated in the same directory.

Issues.Body:
+ feat(bazel): update @bazel/schematics to Bazel 1.0.0

Also removes `build:remote --spawn_strategy=remote` from .bazelrc. It seems that with Bazel 1.0.0 setting `--incompatible_list_based_execution_strategy_selection=false` no longer works around the issue with npm_package that it did when it was added. The error that was originally observed has returned after updating to Bazel 1.0.0:

```
ERROR: /home/circleci/ng/packages/angular_devkit/build_optimizer/BUILD:66:1: Assembling npm package packages/angular_devkit/build_optimizer/npm_package failed: No usable spawn strategy found for spawn with mnemonic Action. Your --spawn_strategy, --genrule_strategy or --strategy flags are probably too strict. Visit https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/7480 for migration advice
```

This commit removes both `‚Äîincompatible_list_based_execution_strategy_selection=false` as well as `build:remote --spawn_strategy=remote` which means that Bazel will do the default behavior of picking the first available strategy from the default list, which is `remote,worker,sandboxed,local`. See https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/7480 for more details.

Not updating to Bazel 1.1.0 yet due to a docker permissions CI issue that was observed on the angular repo that is unresolved. See https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/33367#issuecomment-547643246.

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package

@angular/compiler


### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

The expression parser leaves trailing whitespace when generating some expressions ASTs. This is already a known issue:

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8b5ca670ad74ccc6ca1edd0eea06b9520143d557/packages/compiler/test/render3/r3_ast_absolute_span_spec.ts#L60-L68

This extra whitespace should probably be stripped so that e.g. diagnostic messages do not have trailing whitespace. See https://github.com/angular/vscode-ng-language-service/issues/433 for an example of this affecting the language service.

This is unrelated to #31898.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/8b5ca670ad74ccc6ca1edd0eea06b9520143d557/packages/compiler/test/render3/r3_ast_absolute_span_spec.ts#L60-L68

## üî• Exception or Error

N/A

```
9.0.0-next.*
```

**Anything else relevant?**

Issues.Title: build: remove --nowatchfs flag as --watchfs is a noop on windows now
Issues.Body:
Removing `--nowatchfs` to allow for linux/os x to get back, albeit minimal, performance gains.

`--watchfs` is now a noop on bazel for windows as seen [here](https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/blob/master/src/main/java/com/google/devtools/build/lib/skyframe/WatchServiceDiffAwareness.java#L90)

# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages the are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> This feature request is for @angular/core


### Description
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> A clear and concise description of the problem or missing capability...
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/09a2bb839fffb8f45bf63433ffd3529a48155b8e/packages/core/src/di/injector.ts#L65

`Injector.get('foo')` is deprecated and can make things difficult to maintain because it's typed as `any`
It would be awesome if `new InjectionToken<unknown>('foo')` was a drop-in replacement.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Implement a migrator (for `ng upgrade`) so these values are auto inserted, and then the function signature can finally go away

### Describe alternatives you've considered
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Have you considered any alternative solutions or workarounds?

An alternative is to update the signature to return `unknown`, still deprecated

Issues.Title: @ngtools/webpack build do not wait until AngularCompilerPlugin._make finish like in angular-cli
Issues.Body:
üöÄ Feature request


- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Description

We have big Angular application which is building based on webpack and @ngtools/webpack.  Build takes a lot of time. During some research I found that before starting actually build of files @ngtools/webpack run the following steps

```
AngularCompilerPlugin._setupOptions: 656.320ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._createOrUpdateProgram.ts.createProgram: 25064.073ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._make.resolveEntryModuleFromMain: 17.954ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._listLazyRoutesFromProgram.createProgram: 1.900ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._listLazyRoutesFromProgram.listLazyRoutes: 7292.047ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.getOptionsDiagnostics: 0.349ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.gatherDiagnostics.ts.getSyntacticDiagnostics: 4.739ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.gatherDiagnostics.ts.getSemanticDiagnostics: 18770.113ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit: 34101.066ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._update._emit: 34101.871ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._update: 67271.220ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._make: 67271.619ms

ngcLoader+main.ts+.ngcLoader.AngularCompilerPlugin: 15.984ms
ngcLoader+main.ts+: 45.086ms
running other build files
```
As you see it takes more than one minutes to start building and it wait to finish the command `AngularCompilerPlugin._make`

I tried to run other project using Angular-CLI and the picture is the following

```
AngularCompilerPlugin._setupOptions: 21.142ms
 10% building modules 3/3 modules 0 activeAngularCompilerPlugin._createOrUpdateProgram.ts.createProgram: 4751.113ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._make.resolveEntryModuleFromMain: 7.353ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._getLazyRoutesFromNgtools: 392.109ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.getOptionsDiagnostics: 0.327ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.gatherDiagnostics.ts.getSyntacticDiagnostics: 0.527ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.gatherDiagnostics.ts.getSemanticDiagnostics: 4462.985ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts+environment.ts+.emit: 29.307ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts+main.ts+.emit: 12.554ms
...... some other files emit
AngularCompilerPlugin._emit: 6090.988ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._update._emit: 6091.611ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._update: 11278.420ms
AngularCompilerPlugin._make: 11298.618ms
ngcLoader+main.ts+: 10.050ms
```
As you can see in Angular-CLI after command `AngularCompilerPlugin._emit.ts.gatherDiagnostics.ts.getSemanticDiagnostics`  it shows me all emit files and time which is taking for this operation. In @ngtools/webpack is it still emit all files or just blocked? If it is emitting is it possible to see all files?

I think it takes a lot of time for the step
AngularCompilerPlugin._make: 67271.619ms. 
Do you have any idea how can we improve this time? 
Is it possible to add more logs to see what actually consuming AngularCompilerPlugin?

### Describe the solution you'd like
Add more logs for AngularCompilerPlugin initial step to find which task takes more time.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "@ngtools/webpack build do not wait until AngularCompilerPlugin._make finish like in angular-cli" (#15987)

Issues.Title: Don't write into node_modules by default
Issues.Body:
Currently, `ng build` and possibly other commands write into the node modules directory.

A recently added change #15900 has created the ability to configure CLI to not do this. Which is good, but not great.

This is a feature request to make CLI, **by default**, not write to the node modules directory (other than in `ng update` of course). Perhaps it could default a cache directory next to `angular.json`, or a temp directory, or elsewhere. Regardless, such a change would clarify that a `build` operation takes `node_modules` as pure input, not as a scratch, temp, or output location.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Don't write into node_modules by default" (#15984)

Issues.Title: Integrate Parcel üì¶üöÄ
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request
Intergrate PARCEL : [parceljs.org](https://parceljs.org/)

### Command 
```
- [ ] new
- [x ] build
- [x ] serve
- [x ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [x ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc
```

### Description
Webpack being replaced with parcel or some other bundler. 

Webpack is old 

- On a frequent basis webpack gets out of sync with the current state of the project and will fall behind 1 or N (yes it really can be unlimited in how far back) builds. You're then coding while working with a "phantom build" or "ghost build" a served state of the app which is 1 or N compiles behind what you currently have on disk / in your IDE. this is impossible to flag/debug. You must be aware this can happen and remember to think about it constantly when something iffy is happening (old state of the code clearly on page / not expected behavior) and react by killing all npm instances on your PC and compiling from scratch.

Worst part about this is that it can sometimes be chimeric : a little of the current state a little of an old state. which leads to truly aberrant behavior.
You can waste a lot of time debugging your code over this when in reality your code was 100% correct.
- Speaking of time, webpack is very slow. If you use rollup, parcel or another solution on your angular cli project, initial compilation will be super-fast by comparison and the following re-compilations even more so.
- Webpack has loads of complicated config. Parcel for one has NO config. with that being a possibility why are we trudging on with a dated config-heavy solution?


### Describe the solution you'd like

Parcel would do nicely but I would also be happy with [rollup](https://rollupjs.org/guide/en/) or [pika](https://www.pika.dev/about/)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Integrate Parcel üì¶üöÄ" (#15981)

Issues.Title: ng build --prod differential loading scripts.xxx.js overwrite one another
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) ``` - [ ] new - [ x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ``` ### Is this a regression? I'm not sure ### Description When running ng build --prod on an app with differential loading enabled, and an item exists inside angular.json > projects > your_project > architect > build > options > scripts, the scripts.xxx.js transpiled file is being created twice during the build process, but with the same file name, causing which ever one was compiled first to be overwritten. I am not sure what causes es5 build or es2015 build to be done first, but I have seen it occur in both orders. In each case, whichever one is _last_ will influence the final scripts.xxx.js file. As seen here, you can notice the file names are the same. -> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34222208/67775703-4df6c100-fa2d-11e9-9f28-441a9b49c473.png) Upon close inspection, during the build process, I can verify that, in the case pictured above, the first script generated _was_ indeed transpiled to es2015, and the second script was transpiled to es5. My verification of this -> The first build, which is deleted as soon as the second one completes -> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34222208/67776218-0886c380-fa2e-11e9-8cdb-4e1c354cf547.png) The second build, the one that is present at the end of the build command -> ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34222208/67776020-b9d92980-fa2d-11e9-9943-bd029cde2ad6.png) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. ng new project 2. (for example) npm install tiff.js 3. add "./node_modules/tiff.js/tiff.min.js" to scripts: [] in build in angular.json 4. ng build --prod 5. observe the script.xxx.js file in dist ## üî• Exception or Error 



n/a

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): export protractor builder
Issues.Body:
When using custom builder for dev-server it is not possible to pass additional parameters through protractor builder to it (`ng e2e --additionalParam`) does not work.

Thus, exposing protractor builder (`executeProtractorBuilder`) would allow building custom protractor builders that internally use custom dev-server builders with additional parameters.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): export protractor builder" (#15965)

Issues.Title: fix(tabs): custom QueryList not being cleaned up
Issues.Body: We create a custom `QueryList` called `_tabs` to capture only the tabs that belong to the current tab group, however since it's something that we create manually. it won't be cleaned up automatically. These changes ensure that it's cleaned up.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(tabs): custom QueryList not being cleaned up" (#17548)

Issues.Title: feat(clipboard): add the ability to specify number of attempts in clipboard directive
Issues.Body: Adds a new input to the `cdkCopyToClipboard` directive which allows consumers to set the number of attempts to try and copy their text. We currently have an example of how to implement attempts in the readme, but this feature makes it more convenient so that consumers don't have to do it on a case-by-case basis.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(clipboard): add the ability to specify number of attempts in clipboard directive" (#17547)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/active-descendant-key-manager): emit change event after setting active styles
Issues.Body: Before this change, the "change" event was triggered before the active styles have been set and it was impossible to subscribe to this event and handle items with updated styles (e.g. call change detection). This change fixes it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/active-descendant-key-manager): emit change event after setting active styles" (#17544)

Fixes #17406.

Issues.Title: Error with styles when saving a file
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction


I have an angular 8 project with the installation of angular material as indicated in the documentation, but at the time of running my project I have an error with the styles, since everything works fine until I save a ts or html or scss file when the angular reloads the page the material style is lost

Steps to reproduce:
1. As you can see when I execute the ng serve command it works fine
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16884130/67873701-e52d4880-fb01-11e9-8397-398403d1e4b1.png)

2. When I make a change to a file and save either ts or html or scss the styles are lost and I have to stop the ng serve command to make it work again, some help
 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16884130/67873759-fb3b0900-fb01-11e9-9cdb-afc6d10ba2ed.png)

 
My package.json

{
  "name": "motor",
  "version": "0.0.0",
  "scripts": {
    "ng": "ng",
    "start": "ng serve",
    "build": "ng build",
    "test": "ng test",
    "lint": "ng lint",
    "e2e": "ng e2e"
  },
  "private": true,
  "dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "~8.2.12",
    "@angular/cdk": "~8.2.3",
    "@angular/common": "~8.2.12",
    "@angular/compiler": "~8.2.12",
    "@angular/core": "~8.2.12",
    "@angular/forms": "~8.2.12",
    "@angular/material": "^8.2.3",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "~8.2.12",

Issues.Title: build: add lint rule to enforce coercion static properties for setters
Issues.Body:
Adds a custom tslint rule to enforce that properties which use coercion in a setter also declare a static property to indicate the accepted types to ngtsc. Also handles inherited setters and properties coming from an interface being implemented (necessary to support mixins).

Relates to #17528.

Issues.Title: Disabled radio-button still receives click events
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/angular/xxjmayybegr

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click `Disabled button`: nothing happens
2. Click `Summer` disabled radio button: an alert is emitted.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

Since the radio button is disabled, the `(click)` output should not be emitted.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

The alert is emitted.

#### Environment

- Angular: 8.2.9
- CDK/Material: 8.2.2
- Browser(s): Chromium Version 77.0.3865.90 (Official Build) Built on Ubuntu , running on Ubuntu 18.04 (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Debian
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Disabled radio-button still receives click events" (#17535)

Issues.Title: mat-select should have a "selectionMade" output
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

mat-select has an output that can be used to be notified when selection changes. This is not useful when you need to be notified also when the current selection is **confirmed**, i.e.

1. Current selected option is "foo".
2. User clicks on the select control and clicks again on "foo".

#### Use Case

I don't see why this event shouldn't be notified. Any user selection can be meaningful, not only when the selected option changes.

A concrete use case is when you are implementing a "smart" control that switches from a simple label to an actual select when you click on it and then switches back to a simple label when a selection is made (possibly confirming the currently selected option).

Without the requested feature, the mat-select element will remain visible each time the user confirms the currently selected option, thus breaking the kind of UX that I described.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "mat-select should have a "selectionMade" output" (#17534)

Issues.Title: docs: add package ID prefix to h3's ids
Issues.Body:
This helps avoid collisions in the table of content's sections like
"Directives" and "Services", since now we may show more than one
package entry point in docs (e.g. button and button-testing).

Note that we chose not to add the prefix to individual
class/constant/interface/etc names because it muddles the URL and
is unlikely that we collide on these values.

e.g
```html
<h3 id="material-button-directives" class="docs-header-link docs-api-h3">
```

```html
<h3 id="material-button-testing-interfaces" class="docs-header-link docs-api-h3">
```

Fixes #17526
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "docs: add package ID prefix to h3's ids" (#17527)

Issues.Title: Docs content needs to prefix HTML ids with the package name
Issues.Body:
The docs site now includes API docs for multiple entry points, which means our Table of Contents will need to point to more specific IDs than just "services" and "classes".

A change needs to be made to `entry-point.template.html` so that the `id=...` is prefixed so you have something like `material-button-classes` and `material-button-testing-classes`
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Docs content needs to prefix HTML ids with the package name" (#17526)

Issues.Title: Clearer documentation on TrackBy with respect to index
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

I had an issue adding/ deleting rows to/from Angular material table because the behavior of index isn't clear at all from the documentation.  On first glance, using the let i= index construct seems to suggest that all the work is done for you when in fact you need to specify a trackBy function to keep index synchronised when adding/removing rows from the datasource.  

In my case, I'm using Angular templated forms so I have to create a unique name for each input on every row which I do using the index and I'm sure this can't be an uncommon scenario so it would be good if this was made a bit clearer somewhere.

**Affected documentation page:** [https://material.angular.io/components/table/api](url)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clearer documentation on TrackBy with respect to index" (#17525)

Issues.Title: feat: add coercion for string arrays
Issues.Body:
Adds a utility function to coerce string arrays. This has been very useful for CSS class lists or defining columns for a CDK table.

Handling of `null` and `undefined` (and objects) may be up for discussion. Currently they are mapped via [string interpolation](https://github.com/JanMalch/components/blob/feat/coerce-string-array/src/cdk/coercion/string-array.ts#L15) and [not filtered](https://github.com/JanMalch/components/blob/feat/coerce-string-array/src/cdk/coercion/string-array.spec.ts#L10).

(If this is not just a "small" feature, I'm happy to open up a new issue.)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat: add coercion for string arrays" (#17523)
